summary_points: 1. At Baker Hughes Co.'s 2025 Annual Meeting on May 20, 2025, all nine nominated directors were elected, the executive compensation program was approved, and KPMG LLP was ratified as the independent auditor for fiscal year 2025.
2.  Significant numbers of votes against the election of several directors ranged from 545,188 to 60,552,789 shares, indicating some shareholder dissent.
3.  The advisory vote on the executive compensation program received 811,713,298 votes for and 62,006,455 votes against, suggesting substantial support but also notable opposition.

1. On May 21, 2025, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. granted its CEO, Marc Casper, a $60 million performance-based restricted stock unit award, vesting in 2030, to incentivize shareholder returns and secure his continued leadership.
2.  Over Mr. Casper's tenure, Thermo Fisher's annual revenue increased from $10 billion to $43 billion (May 2025 data).

3. The award's payout is performance-based on total shareholder return (TSR) relative to the S&P 500 from May 1, 2025, to December 31, 2029, with a payout at target if TSR reaches the 50th percentile.

1. At the May 21, 2025 Annual Meeting, Pinnacle West Capital Corporation shareholders elected eleven directors for one-year terms expiring in 2026, with varying levels of "For," "Withheld," and "Broker Non-Vote" across the candidates.

2.  Shareholders approved an advisory vote on executive compensation (92,569,250 For, 3,307,398 Against, 285,186 Abstentions) and an amendment to increase authorized common stock (102,015,773 For, 3,408,833 Against, 309,747 Abstentions), but rejected a shareholder proposal regarding special shareholder meeting improvements.
3. The filing reveals no significant future impacts or risks,  regulatory or legal developments are not discussed.

1. On May 21, 2025, the Iowa Utilities Commission approved a $12.7 million annualized increase in water and wastewater system revenues for Iowa American Water, a subsidiary of American Water Works Company, Inc.

2.  The approved revenue increase reflects a 87.3 million increase in the authorized rate base from $144.7 million in 2021 to $262.1 million in 2025, driven by over $157 million in capital investments.
3.  New rates will become effective after Iowa American Water files for rates reflecting the Commission's order and the IUC completes its review.
1. Kenvue Inc. closed a $750,000,000 underwritten public offering of 4.850% Senior Notes due 2032 on May 22, 2025.
2. The offering's net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.
3. The indenture governing the notes limits Kenvue's ability to incur liens, engage in sale-leaseback transactions, merge, or sell substantially all assets, subject to exceptions.

1. At Amazon.com, Inc.'s May 21, 2025, Annual Meeting of Shareholders, a shareholder proposal to separate the roles of CEO and Chair of the Board was rejected by a vote of 6,407,891,378 against to 1,350,589,329 for.

2.  Numerous other shareholder proposals regarding environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, including advertising risks, emissions reporting, data center climate impact, AI oversight, packaging materials, and warehouse working conditions, were also rejected.

3. The election of directors and ratification of Ernst & Young LLP as auditors for fiscal year 2025 proceeded with significant support, showing strong confidence from shareholders in the current leadership and auditing firm.
1. Robert Scully retired from Zoetis Inc.'s Board of Directors on May 21, 2025, and Mark Stetter was elected to the board the same day.

2.  At the Annual Meeting on May 21, 2025, 88.08% of the voting power of Zoetis Inc.'s common stock was represented, with shareholders approving the election of twelve directors, a non-binding advisory vote on executive compensation, and the ratification of KPMG LLP as the independent auditor, but rejecting a shareholder proposal regarding special shareholder meetings.

3. The shareholder proposal to improve special shareholder meetings received only 50,420,440 votes in favor, substantially less than the 320,662,986 votes against it, indicating limited support for the proposal.
1.  A restructuring plan, initiated in July 2024 and substantially complete by the first quarter of fiscal 2025, is estimated to cost approximately $238 million.
2.  Through April 30, 2025, $14 million in restructuring charges have been recorded, primarily for severance, employee benefits, and site closure costs.
3.  A member of the Board of Directors, Richard Dalzell, plans to sell up to 5,000 shares of company common stock between July 8, 2025, and June 11, 2026.
Failed to analyze filing

1. Copart Inc.'s third-quarter fiscal year 2025 (ended April 30, 2025) results showed a year-over-year increase of 7.5% in revenue ($1.2 billion), 5.1% in gross profit ($552.3 million), and 6.4% in net income attributable to Copart Inc. ($406.6 million).
2.  For the nine months ended April 30, 2025, Copart's revenue increased by 11.2% year-over-year to $3.5 billion.
3. A conference call to discuss the third-quarter fiscal year 2025 results was scheduled for May 22, 2025, at 5:30 p.m. Eastern Time, with a replay available until September 2025.

1. At AvalonBay Communities' May 21, 2025 annual meeting, shareholders re-elected eleven directors, with varying levels of support ranging from 92.6% (Susan Swanezy) to 97.9% (Ronald L. Havner, Jr.) approval.
2.  Shareholders approved executive compensation with 121,084,118 votes in favor (92.1%), and ratified Ernst & Young LLP as auditors with 125,075,242 votes in favor (94.1%).
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this 8-K filing.

1. Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. completed a public offering of 4,750,000 shares of common stock at $225.00 per share on May 22, 2025, with underwriters exercising an option to purchase an additional 712,500 shares.
2. The offering raised approximately $1.19 billion in net proceeds after expenses,  as of May 22, 2025.

3.  Take-Two Interactive faces future risks including the timely release and market acceptance of its games, international business risks, interest rate volatility, inflation, and currency exchange rate fluctuations.

1. Deckers Outdoor Corp. reported record revenue of $4.99 billion and diluted EPS of $6.33 for fiscal year 2025, representing a 16% and 30% increase year-over-year respectively (as of March 31, 2025).
2.  The company's board appointed Cynthia Davis as Chair, replacing Michael Devine who retired, and reduced the board's size from 11 to 10 members, effective May 22, 2025.

3.  Deckers projects net sales between $890 million and $910 million and diluted earnings per share between $0.62 and $0.67 for the first fiscal quarter of 2026 (ending June 30, 2025), but will not provide full-year guidance due to macroeconomic uncertainty.
1. At the Principal Financial Group, Inc. annual shareholders meeting on May 20, 2025, shareholders elected four Class III directors, each for a three-year term expiring in 2028.
2.  The advisory vote to approve executive compensation received 142,675,128 votes for and 7,735,191 votes against, with 545,028 abstentions and 19,322,185 broker non-votes.
3. The ratification of the appointment of independent registered public accountants received 160,644,877 votes for and 9,439,069 votes against, with 193,586 abstentions and 0 broker non-votes.
1. On May 21, 2025, ONEOK, Inc. shareholders approved the ONEOK, Inc. 2025 Equity Incentive Plan and the ONEOK, Inc. 2025 Employee Stock Award Program, replacing their 2018 counterparts.
2.  The 2025 Equity Incentive Plan authorizes the issuance of up to 19,148,971 shares of common stock, while the 2025 Employee Stock Award Program authorizes 700,000 shares.
3. The 2025 ESAP awards shares based on share price reaching $1 increments above a base price, with additional discretionary awards possible at the Board's discretion.

1. On May 19, 2025, Qualcomm Inc. completed a registered public offering of $1,500,000,000 in senior unsecured notes, split across three tranches with maturities in 2030, 2032, and 2035, and interest rates of 4.5%, 4.75%, and 5% respectively.
2.  The offering raised a gross $1,491,710,000 for Qualcomm.
3. The notes are redeemable by Qualcomm at the applicable redemption price, as described in the note documents, and contain customary events of default including bankruptcy or insolvency.
1. VeriSign Inc.'s stockholders approved an amendment to limit the liability of certain officers, as permitted by Delaware law, on May 22, 2025.
2.  In the 2025 annual meeting, the proposal to limit officer liability passed with 71,483,725 votes for and 7,587,450 votes against.
3. A stockholder proposal regarding stockholder action by written consent was rejected, receiving only 4,547,136 votes in favor compared to 74,230,799 against.

1. Workday, Inc. reported total revenues of $2.240 billion for the fiscal first quarter ended April 30, 2025, a 12.6% increase year-over-year, driven by a 13.4% increase in subscription revenues to $2.059 billion.

2.  Operating income for the first quarter of fiscal 2026 was $39 million (1.8% of revenue), down significantly from $64 million (3.2% of revenue) in the same period last year, primarily due to $166 million in restructuring expenses.
3. Workday's Board of Directors authorized a new share repurchase program on May 22, 2025, allowing for the repurchase of up to an additional $1.0 billion of Class A common stock.
1. CDW Corp's shareholder proposal regarding the right to act by written consent was narrowly defeated at the May 20, 2025 annual meeting.
2.  Eleven directors were elected at the May 20, 2025 annual meeting, their terms expiring in 2026.
3. Shareholder proposals concerning executive compensation and auditor ratification were approved at the May 20, 2025 annual meeting.

1. Intuit Inc. reported strong Q3 2025 financial results (ended April 30, 2025), with total revenue growth of 15% to $7.8 billion, and raised its full-year guidance for fiscal 2025 across all metrics.
2.  Year-over-year (YoY),  Credit Karma revenue increased by 31% to $579 million in Q3 2025, exceeding previous guidance.

3. Intuit projects TurboTax Live revenue to grow by 47% to $2.0 billion in fiscal year 2025, representing approximately 40% of total Consumer Group revenue; however, they also expect a 1-point decrease in TurboTax's share of total IRS returns due to a decline in "pay-nothing" customers.
1. Ross Stores' Q1 2025 earnings per share were $1.47, slightly up from $1.46 in Q1 2024, while net income decreased to $479 million from $488 million.
2.  Comparable store sales were flat year-over-year in Q1 2025, despite improved monthly sales performance throughout the quarter.

3. Ross Stores withdrew its annual sales and earnings guidance for fiscal year 2025 due to heightened macroeconomic uncertainty and the unpredictable impact of tariffs, projecting Q2 2025 earnings per share to be $1.40 to $1.55 (compared to $1.59 in Q2 2024), with an estimated $0.11 to $0.16 per share cost impact from tariffs.
1. As of February 2030, the company will have a $2.5 billion unsecured revolving credit agreement with a group of banks, replacing a prior $1.5 billion agreement that expired in February 2026.
2. As of April 27, 2025, approximately $15.9 billion remained available for future stock repurchases under the company's $20 billion repurchase program.

3.  The company is cooperating with multiple government investigations regarding China customer shipments, export controls compliance, and federal award applications, with no reasonable estimate of potential losses or penalties.
1. Autodesk's Q1 FY26 (ended April 30, 2025) revenue increased by 15% year-over-year to $1.6 billion.
2.  Stephen W. Hope, Autodesk's Senior Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer, will step down at the end of August 2025; Janesh Moorjani will assume his responsibilities.
3. Autodesk's FY26 business outlook predicts revenue between $6.925 and $6.995 billion, with free cash flow projected between $2.1 and $2.2 billion.
1. Cencora, Inc. completed the sale of €1,000,000,000 aggregate principal amount of senior notes due in 2028 and 2032 on May 22, 2025.
2. The 2028 notes bear interest at a rate of 2.875% per year, while the 2032 notes bear interest at a rate of 3.625% per year, both payable annually in arrears beginning May 22, 2026.
3.  The indentures governing the notes contain covenants that limit Cencora's ability to create liens, engage in sale and leaseback transactions, and undertake certain mergers or asset sales.
1. Ball Corporation's Chief Financial Officer, Howard Yu, resigned on May 22, 2025, effective June 30, 2025, due to a mutual agreement, and  Daniel Rabbitt was appointed as interim CFO.
2. The company reaffirmed its previously issued full-year comparable diluted earnings per share growth outlook of 11-14% for 2025.
3.  Yu's departure is not related to any disagreements regarding accounting practices, financial statements, internal controls, or operations.
1. On May 21, 2025, Old Dominion Freight Line, Inc. shareholders approved the 2025 Stock Incentive Plan, which had previously been approved by the Board of Directors.
2.  Shareholder approval of the emission reduction target proposal was rejected at the Annual Meeting held on May 21, 2025, receiving only 27,731,468 votes in favor.
3.  A $0.28 per share quarterly cash dividend, representing a 7.7% increase from June 2024, was declared by the Board of Directors on May 22, 2025, payable on June 18, 2025.
1. As of March 29, 2025, the company had $1,929.4 million in total cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash.
2.  During fiscal year 2025, the company's total capital expenditures were $216.2 million.
3. In fiscal year 2024, the company converted 3.0 million shares of Class B common stock into Class A common stock.

1. Ralph Lauren Corporation exceeded expectations for both fourth-quarter and full-year fiscal 2025 revenue, with fourth-quarter revenue up 10% in constant currency and full-year revenue up 8% in constant currency.
2.  For the full fiscal year 2025, operating margins increased by 150 basis points to 14%, exceeding the long-term target.

3. Ralph Lauren provides a preliminary outlook for fiscal 2026, predicting low-single-digit net revenue growth on a constant currency basis and modest operating margin expansion, reflecting caution about the global operating environment.
1. On May 21, 2025, Seagate Technology Holdings plc approved a $5 billion common stock repurchase program with no expiration date.
2.  The company is holding an analyst and investor day on May 22, 2025, to discuss the repurchase program and new financial targets through fiscal year 2028.
3. The timing and amount of future repurchases will depend on Seagate's financial position, results, cash flow, and other factors.
Failed to analyze filing
1. Analog Devices, Inc. reported fiscal second-quarter 2025 revenue of $2.64 billion, a 22% year-over-year increase, exceeding the high end of its guidance.
2.  Trailing twelve-month operating cash flow reached $3.9 billion (39% of revenue), and free cash flow was $3.3 billion (34% of revenue).

3.  The company forecasts $2.75 billion in revenue for the third quarter of fiscal 2025 (ending August 2, 2025), with an expected reported operating margin of approximately 27.2% and adjusted operating margin of approximately 41.5%.
1. Quest Diagnostics Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on May 15, 2025, where all director nominees were elected and shareholder proposals were voted on.
2.  The advisory resolution to approve executive officer compensation received 85,922,577 votes for and 8,570,674 votes against.
3. A stockholder proposal regarding calling a special meeting of stockholders was not approved, receiving significantly fewer votes for (9,480,355) than against (84,410,956).

1. Align Technology, Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on May 21, 2025, where stockholders approved an amendment to the 2005 Incentive Plan to increase the number of shares authorized for issuance.

2.  Shareholder votes on proposals ranged widely;  Proposal 6 (allowing stockholders owning 25% of outstanding common stock to call a special meeting) received significantly fewer "For" votes (38,706,293) than "Against" votes (14,717,639).
3. The amended 2005 Incentive Plan, effective May 21, 2025, increases the maximum number of shares that may be awarded and sold under the plan to 34,668,895.
1. Crown Castle Inc. eliminated all supermajority voting requirements and certain outdated provisions from its Restated Certificate of Incorporation, effective May 21, 2025.
2. At the May 21, 2025 annual meeting, the advisory vote to approve named executive officer compensation received 346,381,062 votes for and 26,151,894 votes against.
3.  The Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation includes extensive restrictions on share ownership to maintain REIT tax status.

1. On May 21, 2025, Diamondback Energy, Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders, resulting in a leadership transition with Travis D. Stice becoming Executive Chairman and Kaes Van’t Hof becoming Chief Executive Officer.
2.  Shareholder votes on Proposal 4, regarding executive severance arrangements, resulted in 205,457,636 votes against and only 55,652,005 votes in favor.
3.  David L. Houston retired from his position as a director, effective May 21, 2025.
1. Keurig Dr Pepper Inc. declared a $0.23 per share quarterly dividend, payable July 11, 2025.
2. As of May 21, 2025, Keurig Dr Pepper Inc. reported annual revenue exceeding $15 billion.
3.  An 8-K filing was submitted to the SEC on May 21, 2025.
1. Crown Castle Inc. declared a quarterly dividend of $1.0625 per share payable on June 30, 2025, to stockholders of record at the close of business on June 13, 2025.
2.  As of May 21, 2025, Crown Castle Inc. owns and leases over 40,000 cell towers and approximately 90,000 route miles of fiber.
3. Future dividends are subject to the approval of Crown Castle's Board of Directors.
1. Andrew Witty resigned from his position as a director of UnitedHealth Group Incorporated, effective May 20, 2025.
2.  This 8-K filing, dated May 21, 2025, reports the immediate resignation of a director, and that he will not stand for re-election at the annual shareholder meeting on June 2, 2025.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned beyond the director's resignation.
1. At FirstEnergy Corp.'s May 21, 2025, annual shareholder meeting, all board nominees were elected, though several received significant "against" votes ranging from 6,613,165 to 16,575,405.
2.  Shareholder proposal regarding a report on lobbying activities and policies failed to receive approval, garnering only 38,583,584 votes in favor versus 439,112,618 against.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as the company's independent registered public accounting firm for the 2025 fiscal year, receiving 505,600,965 votes in favor.

1. Targa Resources Corp.'s 2025 Annual Meeting on May 20, 2025, resulted in the election of four Class III directors (Waters S. Davis IV, Rene R. Joyce, Caron A. Lawhorn, and Matthew J. Meloy) for three-year terms expiring in 2028, ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as independent auditors for 2025, and advisory approval of named executive officer compensation for fiscal year 2024.

2.  Significant shareholder dissent was observed in the director elections, with votes against ranging from 1.4 million to 23.8 million shares out of approximately 180 million votes cast for each nominee.
3. The advisory vote on executive compensation had approximately 10.3 million votes against, indicating a level of shareholder concern regarding executive pay packages as of December 31, 2024.
1.  On May 16, 2025, Intercontinental Exchange, Inc. held its annual stockholder meeting, where shareholders elected ten directors to serve one-year terms.
2.  The advisory resolution on executive compensation was approved by stockholders with 457,032,009 votes for and 27,860,556 votes against.
3. Stockholders approved amendments to the company's Certificate of Incorporation to implement voting limitations for regulatory compliance, with 487,751,664 votes for and 214,016 votes against.
1. Mosaic Co. amended and restated its credit agreement on May 16, 2025, extending the maturity date of its $2.5 billion credit facility from August 19, 2026, to May 16, 2030.
2.  The amended agreement reduces rates on unused commitment fees and provides Mosaic with more flexibility under restrictive covenants.
3. The amendment provides Mosaic with a longer-term credit facility until May 16, 2030, reducing financial risk associated with refinancing in the near term.
1. On May 19, 2025, FMC Corp issued $750,000,000 of 8.450% Fixed-to-Fixed Reset Rate Subordinated Notes due 2055, with the closing expected on May 27, 2025.
2. The net proceeds from the note sale are expected to be approximately $741 million.
3. The underwriting agreement contains representations, warranties, conditions, and covenants, including indemnification and contribution provisions for certain liabilities.

1. Phillips 66's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders resulted in the election of two Phillips 66 nominees (Robert W. Pease and Nigel Hearne) and two Elliott Management nominees (Sigmund L. Cornelius and Michael A. Heim), while John E. Lowe and Howard Ungerleider were not re-elected.

2. The shareholder vote to declassify the Board of Directors did not receive the required 80% affirmative vote, despite significant support, while Elliott’s proposal for annual director resignations was overwhelmingly rejected.
3.  Based on the preliminary results (as of May 21, 2025), the Board recognizes shareholder preference for annual elections and remains committed to declassification in the future.

1. On May 21, 2025, American Tower Corporation priced a €500.0 million (approximately $562.0 million) registered public offering of senior unsecured notes due 2032, with a 3.625% annual interest rate and issued at 99.994% of face value.
2.  The net proceeds of €496.8 million (approximately $558.4 million) will be used to repay existing indebtedness and for general corporate purposes.
3. American Tower intends to use the net proceeds to partially repay its $6.0 billion senior unsecured multicurrency revolving credit facility.
1. Zoetis Inc. declared a $0.50 per share dividend for the third quarter of 2025, payable on September 3, 2025, to shareholders of record as of July 18, 2025.
2. Zoetis reported $9.3 billion in revenue for 2024, with approximately 13,800 employees.
3.  The filing contains forward-looking statements regarding business plans and future financial performance, subject to various risks and uncertainties detailed in their 10-K and 10-Q filings.

1. On May 19, 2025, Consolidated Edison Inc. held its annual meeting, where shareholders voted to elect the board of directors, ratify the appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as independent accountants, and provide an advisory vote on named executive officer compensation.

2.  Significant opposition was registered against the election of several board members, with "against" votes ranging from 1.86 million (Dwight A. McBride) to 21.9 million (John F. Killian),  out of approximately 268 million total votes cast (excluding broker non-votes).
3.  The advisory vote on executive compensation resulted in 222 million shares voted "for" and 17.3 million shares voted "against," with 1.5 million abstentions and 51.6 million broker non-votes.
